] perceived, in reading in the National
Intelligencer description of the contiagra-
tion at Alexandria, an application of the
word carry, Tor rather its deriatives) which
appears little laughable in this section OF
the Union. The Editors says, "nor were our
Georgetown neighbors bchind-hand: with
great spirit they went down i'll numbers, in
carriages, and on foot carrying also, it is be-
lievcd, their engine" 1t is supposed to be
near ten miles from Georgetown to Alexan-
tlria, no small distance to carry an engine;--
but as there were SO many persons sin car
riages on horseback, and OH foot" the bur-
den could not have been very heavy the
only difficulty would have been to give each
an equal share But all this is trihing,
for we are told in the next sentence that "aN
the MARINES on the station, were carried
down by CAPT. Hogvie, under the orders of
Col. Henderson, ndca,7ying an engine with
them" Now this is as great burden as any
man could carry. IF the Marines had car
rcd Capt. Howle, it would have appeared
more probable, or even if they had placed
him, as kind of branci.-pipe- on the
top of the engine they were carrying with
them, it would have looked more natural.
1t would be good thing if the Wilmington
folks could carry their engines, forthey (the
engines) sometimcs,b s,break down, or stick in
the mud. Carrying would prevent this.

on hand al reduced prices, whole sale or retail.

their advantage to give us call, as we have

press Shingles of various qualities; Pannel, first
and second common white pine Boards well sea-
soned; hearts Pine and Hemlock l'oards, Scant-
ling and Joist of various qualities, lengths and

specked and curled Maple Boards, Plank and
Scantling. Also. Cherry Scantling; inch and
half inch Walnut Boards, and a variety OF other
articles not enumerated.


N. B. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business, will find it much to their adj
vantage to make application to us, as we are
disposed to sell on reasonable terms; and the
stand is we'll known to be as good as any in the
Borough.

makes his lather of hot or cold water At
breakfast Sir Walter asked for roll in
preference to toast; and it is curious fact.
that he drank two cups of tea and only one
Of coffee. We have also been informed, up
on undoubted authority, that he said to the

1t is intended that the Iiccla shall leave the
Thames on the 1st of May next, and steer her
course pretty directly for Spitzbergen Here
she will be left IN charge of a small portion of
the crew, while the rest of the company, in two
divisions, will pursue the main objects OF the en-
terprize, with boats constructed for that Pur..
pose. Capt. Parry, and Lieutenant Ross VIII
proceed directly towards the Pole, and get I'M
der il if possible; while Lieut.. Foster, in com
mand Of another party, will branch out in dif-
ferent course, TO find out, if he can, into what
part of the northern seas the whales, which of
late years have become scarce in those places
which they formerly frequeated, have now liked
their abode. At Spitzbergen, the boats will be
placed upon sledges, and drawn along by such
animal as may be met with (Shetisnd PONIES, as
we have stated, will probably be used IN the first
iDstance) and in case offalure Of animals for the
purpose, the crew will drag the boats until they
come to open water, when the barks will be
launched from their sledges and rowed in their
proper element; and thus alternately serve the
purposes of land carriage and aquatic barges.


When the respective parties have made such OBJ
scrvations and researches as they may be ena-
bled to accomplish, they will return in similar
way to the Hecla, and the objects of the Expe-
dton being completed they will sail direct for
England. Paper.

Departed this life, at Cecilton, Md. on Satur~
day night, Jan. Goth after an illness oftwenty four
hours, Mrs. PHEBE II. NOWLAND, wife of AL
FRED C. NOWLAND, Esq. and eldest daugh-
ter of Hyland b. Pennington, Esq. Merchant Of
that village, in the 24th year OF her age. Her
remains were deposited in St. Stephens Church
yard on Monday, the 22d of January, attended
by her numerous relatives and friends.


The death of this truly amiable lady, has left
a chasm in Society that will long remain. To a
temper unusually mild, she united sweetness
and gentleness ofmanners that fascinated all who
became acquainted with her. Her mind was
stored with all the requirements that could be
derived from polite education; her judgment
was beyond her years, and she was looked up to
as an example Of prudence and discretion in the
polite circle in which she moved. At the age
of nine years she lost an affectonate mother, and
her surviving parent placed her at the female
seminary at Lets, in Pennsylvania, where she
took very pious turn, and on her return home
from the seminary, at the early age of fourteen
years, she united hersclfto the Methodist Church,
Of which she continued a worthy member, until
her GOD, of hisinfnifc wisdom, called her to his
own bosom. The poor Of the neighbourbood
have often felt the liberalty Of her disposition.
She has frequently been known to visit them in
their sick rooms, and give her mite, and to attend
to see their wants alleviated. She has LETT to
mourn her loss an atectionate husband, father,
brothers and sisters. In short she possessed
all the virtures of truly amiable and femenine
character; and her loss will be sincerely mourn
ed by all who knew her.


Nor genial sun nor blooming flower,


Nor summers breeze, as DER thy grave,


1t softly sweeps, at dewy eve,


Still watts affections deepest sigh,


Still shall memory linger nigh,


And weep, forever weep the severed tie.

''ut when he pleas'd to shew't his speech,


In lofiness of sound was rich;


A BaJylonish dialect,


Which learned pedants much Affect


1t was a party-color'o dress,


Ofpatch'd and py-baM languages.


Twas English cut on 'sreck and Latin,


Like fustna heretofore on satin.


1t had an odd promiscuous tone,

A leash of languages at once"


Quotations and phrases in the Dead and
Foreign Languages, give classical and
learned air to composition, but it is doubtful
whether they give general pleasure. The
number of learnedly educated persons, is so
small, that the circle in which they can be
understood and appreciated must be very
limited; hence general diffusion OF their
influence is impossible. If men write for
the ediicaton or amusement of the public,
they should accommodate every word and
phrase to the comprehension Of those ad-
dressed. 1t is quite natural for men to ex
ercise and exhibit their attanncnts, but it is
not always expedient and pleasing Striving
to appear learned, they render themselves
obscure. They astonsh, but they do moi
please--they perplex, but they do not teach
Wrapped in their own splendor the, glide
like midnight meteors through the air, won,
dercd at, but misunderstood or incomprehen
sible. Writers would lose nothing in effec'
or celebrity by expressing themselves in the
vermacular tongue. Learned men would
understand them fully as well. and unlearn-
ed men, much better.


There is scarcely any thing more disagreed
bic to those who cannot understand it,than II
discover in the midst OF train of arguments
precepts or descriptions, sentence, phrase
or word. in foreign or dead language. Ev.
cry thing seems suddenly convulsed and
dark. A kind of deadly apoplexy seize'
the mind, and violently destroys that life
vigor and equilibrium, which buoyed it uE
through its conceptions.


1t is satisfaction to know that the Eng.
lish language is sufficiently copious to fur
nish words for the expression OF every
thought that the head can generate or i'm
bibe, or emotion the heart can feel. 1t il
in the language of Cowper,


"Expressive, energetic and refined"
Every idea may be told, every feeling trans
cribrd, and all be embellshed and beautified
The Genius of English writer's, has render
ed it perfect, and although, they are indebt
ed to foreign lands and olden times, for man,
of the materials which compose it, yet thu
workmanship and superstructure are thei
own:-they have reared splendid habita
ton, the foundation of which is indestruct'
BILE. and immovable. Then why should w
seek the empty pomp of useless learning t.
bedizen that which is independently, and IN
srinsically, fair and beneficial. II.

sal.

Trouble among he Bacheirs.--Cicn. M'Clure,
the hero Of Newark, has made war upon the
bachelors of New York, At the head Of an army
of Dogs and puppies! He has introduced a bin
into the Legislature of that State TO repeal the

from on Bachelors between the ages of 30 and
As years. The bachelors of the city of New
York have called meeting to take measures to
prevent the passage of the bill and to express
their Indignation at the proposition.

Sir Jtulter Scott III Pdris.--NVe have
been a good deal amused with the para
graphs which have been appearing in the
French papers. concerning our illustrious
countryman, the author of Waverly. The
good people of Paris seem to think there
must be something supernatural about him,
and attach an importance to his every word


and action, which is sufficiently ludicrous


There is no mistake more absurd, though


there are few more common, than to sup


pose that every thing that comes out of an


authors mouth must be oracular-that, be-


cause he has 1oritten books, he must also


sneak books.-As long as he retains the at


tributes of humanity, Socrates himself


must, at times, be commonplace. A Mil


ton give utterance to plain prose, and q


northern magician expressed himself moi


unlike southern Maccaroni. The simple


hearted Parisians, however, do not seem tc
have wit sufficient to make this discovery
and, accordingly, when any one was foriu'


nate enough to catch some stray sentence
!, which may have dropped from Sir Walter


Scott, at any Of their public exhibitions ol


l., Il h.., c,l lar.
: it his duty to have it set down in the letter
press, and distributed over Europe, to awe
: and delight admiring millions. We shall ia
yor onr readers with specimen of some o
this twaddle, which has been published I'm
der the name of Sir Walter Scott. We dc
not vouch for the exact words being founc
in anv one of the French Journals, but de
tails of similar interest are appearing dali,


in all OF them. yesterday great sensa


ton was excited by Sir Walter Scott's Wis
it to Galigani's reading room. lhe lllustri
B trious stranger read seven lines of the Jour


nal des Debats, and one sentence and hai


of the EtoHe. Though a little lame there Is
great deal of vivacity in the manner IL
which he walks, and the pencilling OF his
eyebrows is full of expression. We were
5 fortunate enoug to hear him remark, thai


he often loks into a newspaper with much
pleasure. .'-".rhe Great Unknown at
tracted much attention on Tuesday, by pass


ing over the Pont .Ncuf at Q O'Clock, accom-
panied by his amiabe daughter, Miss Anne
Scott-Her father directed the lady's at


tenton to the river; and in a soft but rather
melancholy tone of voice, said to her, That
is the Seine.' His daughter fixed her eyes
S upon it for moment and then both passed


on."-"Last night Sir Walter Scott was al


the Odeon. The audience thought it theii


duty to gaze intently upon him during the
whole of the evening. Sir Walter wore a


black coat, but we observed with regret that
: his ocket-handkerchicf, instead ot being o.
: white cambrick, was of yellow silk. a dis
plav of this kind, however, may not be con-
sidered breach OF etiquette in Edinburgh
= In passing the bust of Moiere in the Saioor
the Great Unknown said, in English, to
r Miss Scott, that is Moliere.' "-"This NOR
= ming Sir Waltar Scott was observed shaving
: at the bedroom window OF his hotel, in thu
q Rue 7iveH. The superiority of English ra


zors has long been acknowledged, nut w
U have seldom seen one used so dexterousl.
: as by the author Of Waverly. We have no


vet been enabled to ascertain whether n

be hired out. for the purpose of raising funds
to defray the expenses of sending them ia
Havti. or Liberia, whichever they may
choose.

A woman of incorporate habits named
Staples, belonging to Kittery. Me. was found
dead in an engine house in Portsmouth. N.
II on the night of the 18th inst. She was
seen in that ncighborhood or hours be-
fore, and had small Jug of spirits with her
when found; she had probably perished
from cold and intoxication.


An advertisement appeared in London
paper few days ago, offering parrot for
sale. which was represented to be "perfect-
" good tempercd-could laugh sing and talk
and was well worth the attention of any
person in want of a Comhanion.


Mr.. Buchanan, OF Pennsylvania. IN his
speech in the House of Representatives, on
Friday week, said he felt proud-and well
he might-to say that "his native State had
not only paid her officers and soldiers more
literally than any other state, but had also
provided for her militia, who served during
the Revolutionary War"


II Loud CaH-A woman called at the
house of Mr.. Hays in N. Y. last evening, and
requested him to go with her, as her hus-
band had sworn to kill the first man that
came into the house, and she wanted him to
go first to protect her. We should not
think that even the high constable would be
desirous of many such calls.


The Raleigh Star says that the stage
crossed the Roanoke, near Warrenton oil
the ice, on the second instant, circumstance
which has not occurred before since '83.-
We learn that the Cape Fear was frozen
over at Ayerashrouyh also for the first time
since '82.

full articles.article:
moon, otherwise dark, will be enlightened
by tho blaze of Venus am now man ad


vanced in years. yet Inever remember to
have seen a phenomena similar to the one
am describing. Therefore propose rising
on the morning of the 22d of the Cd month
(February) at h. So min. or rather before,
and look at this interesting event; conclud-


ing that others alike interested will do the
same. 1t is not to be expected that man
kind, of grovcllng appetites, will desire any
thing of the kind; yet it is to be hoped that
there are youth of both sexes who are en-
deavoring to become conspicuous in arts and
science, who will profit themselves and the
community at large, by making few practi-
cal experiments, not confding altogether in
those made by Sir Isaac Newton-whch,


like system of old worlds, is near dissolv-


ing, and when quite dissolved, will afford
materials from whence entire new worlds
will be formed hence doing away old
things all become new; even creation is new
every moment and will so continue world


without end, AMEN.

full articles.headline: Tor the Wilmingtonian.
full articles.article:
] perceived, in reading in the National
Intelligencer description of the contiagra-
tion at Alexandria, an application of the
word carry, Tor rather its deriatives) which
appears little laughable in this section OF
the Union. The Editors says, "nor were our
Georgetown neighbors bchind-hand: with
great spirit they went down i'll numbers, in
carriages, and on foot carrying also, it is be-
lievcd, their engine" 1t is supposed to be
near ten miles from Georgetown to Alexan-
tlria, no small distance to carry an engine;--
but as there were SO many persons sin car
riages on horseback, and OH foot" the bur-
den could not have been very heavy the
only difficulty would have been to give each
an equal share But all this is trihing,
for we are told in the next sentence that "aN
the MARINES on the station, were carried
down by CAPT. Hogvie, under the orders of
Col. Henderson, ndca,7ying an engine with
them" Now this is as great burden as any
man could carry. IF the Marines had car
rcd Capt. Howle, it would have appeared
more probable, or even if they had placed
him, as kind of branci.-pipe- on the
top of the engine they were carrying with
them, it would have looked more natural.
1t would be good thing if the Wilmington
folks could carry their engines, forthey (the
engines) sometimcs,b s,break down, or stick in
the mud. Carrying would prevent this.


Q.

full articles.headline: Ilumber For Sale.
full articles.article:
The subscribers intend to decline the Lumber
Business early this Spring, and offer their Stock
on hand al reduced prices, whole sale or retail.
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find il to
their advantage to give us call, as we have
general assortment, consisting of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles of various qualities; Pannel, first
and second common white pine Boards well sea-
soned; hearts Pine and Hemlock l'oards, Scant-
ling and Joist of various qualities, lengths and
Sizes Poplar Plank, Boards and Scantling; plain,
specked and curled Maple Boards, Plank and
Scantling. Also. Cherry Scantling; inch and
half inch Walnut Boards, and a variety OF other
articles not enumerated.


N. B. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business, will find it much to their adj
vantage to make application to us, as we are
disposed to sell on reasonable terms; and the
stand is we'll known to be as good as any in the
Borough.


EZRA IIOOPES,


JOSEPH THOMAS.
wilmington, I'd mo. 1st, 1927. 2o-t.

full articles.article:
on Washington's birth day, at 3 hours
anu 50 minutes, a. M. (time at Wilmington,
delaware, } there will happen an occultation
" me planet Venus. behind the moons disk,
W the Inhabitants who live in high north
'a.''udes, and on the same meridian of Will
a'hs'on. Astronomers, no doubt, living in
muse high latitudes, will make their calcu-
;a''ons accordingly; yet to US calculation
:. unnecessary, as we shall only perceive that
h. sAe Time of their conjunction, viz: at 3
,'su's s as minutes. nothing more will be ap.
en' TO us than beholding (if the air is
NJ M the light of Venus, mingling with the
0ns southern horn or lower limb. and
III. tbA0'y torminga crescence of light around

Ill my conjectures, the body of the

makes his lather of hot or cold water At
breakfast Sir Walter asked for roll in
preference to toast; and it is curious fact.
that he drank two cups of tea and only one
Of coffee. We have also been informed, up
on undoubted authority, that he said to the
amiable Miss Ann Scott, but with much gen
tleness, you have given me rather little su-
gar" We cannot afford room at present
for any more of these extracts, but any
such anecdotes which we may meet with,
if equally instructive, we shall be sure TO lay
before our readers.-Edinburgh Observer.


1t is intended that the Iiccla shall leave the
Thames on the 1st of May next, and steer her
course pretty directly for Spitzbergen Here
she will be left IN charge of a small portion of
the crew, while the rest of the company, in two
divisions, will pursue the main objects OF the en-
terprize, with boats constructed for that Pur..
pose. Capt. Parry, and Lieutenant Ross VIII
proceed directly towards the Pole, and get I'M
der il if possible; while Lieut.. Foster, in com
mand Of another party, will branch out in dif-
ferent course, TO find out, if he can, into what
part of the northern seas the whales, which of
late years have become scarce in those places
which they formerly frequeated, have now liked
their abode. At Spitzbergen, the boats will be
placed upon sledges, and drawn along by such
animal as may be met with (Shetisnd PONIES, as
we have stated, will probably be used IN the first
iDstance) and in case offalure Of animals for the
purpose, the crew will drag the boats until they
come to open water, when the barks will be
launched from their sledges and rowed in their
proper element; and thus alternately serve the
purposes of land carriage and aquatic barges.


When the respective parties have made such OBJ
scrvations and researches as they may be ena-
bled to accomplish, they will return in similar
way to the Hecla, and the objects of the Expe-
dton being completed they will sail direct for
England. Paper.

full articles.headline: OBITUARY.
full articles.article:
Departed this life, at Cecilton, Md. on Satur~
day night, Jan. Goth after an illness oftwenty four
hours, Mrs. PHEBE II. NOWLAND, wife of AL
FRED C. NOWLAND, Esq. and eldest daugh-
ter of Hyland b. Pennington, Esq. Merchant Of
that village, in the 24th year OF her age. Her
remains were deposited in St. Stephens Church
yard on Monday, the 22d of January, attended
by her numerous relatives and friends.


The death of this truly amiable lady, has left
a chasm in Society that will long remain. To a
temper unusually mild, she united sweetness
and gentleness ofmanners that fascinated all who
became acquainted with her. Her mind was
stored with all the requirements that could be
derived from polite education; her judgment
was beyond her years, and she was looked up to
as an example Of prudence and discretion in the
polite circle in which she moved. At the age
of nine years she lost an affectonate mother, and
her surviving parent placed her at the female
seminary at Lets, in Pennsylvania, where she
took very pious turn, and on her return home
from the seminary, at the early age of fourteen
years, she united hersclfto the Methodist Church,
Of which she continued a worthy member, until
her GOD, of hisinfnifc wisdom, called her to his
own bosom. The poor Of the neighbourbood
have often felt the liberalty Of her disposition.
She has frequently been known to visit them in
their sick rooms, and give her mite, and to attend
to see their wants alleviated. She has LETT to
mourn her loss an atectionate husband, father,
brothers and sisters. In short she possessed
all the virtures of truly amiable and femenine
character; and her loss will be sincerely mourn
ed by all who knew her.


Nor genial sun nor blooming flower,


Nor summers breeze, as DER thy grave,


1t softly sweeps, at dewy eve,


Still watts affections deepest sigh,


Still shall memory linger nigh,


And weep, forever weep the severed tie.

full articles.headline: A Miller Wanted.
full articles.article:
A single, sober, industrious, and honest man,
we'll acquainted with attending Grist Mill, and
has some knowledge Of Farming, will meet with
employment the ensuing year, by applying to
the subscribers


ALSO, single man of similar habits, &c. who
is well acquainted with Farming in all its branch
es.


SAMUEL & VIM METER,


Near Mewark, DEL
February 1, 1897. 20--4t.

full articles.headline: Tor tic TTllming,oaian.
full articles.article:
''ut when he pleas'd to shew't his speech,


In lofiness of sound was rich;


A BaJylonish dialect,


Which learned pedants much Affect


1t was a party-color'o dress,


Ofpatch'd and py-baM languages.


Twas English cut on 'sreck and Latin,


Like fustna heretofore on satin.


1t had an odd promiscuous tone,


As ifhe'd tslk'd three parts in one;


Which made some think when he did gabble,


They heard three laborers of Dabc,


Or Cerberus himself pronounce


A leash of languages at once"


Quotations and phrases in the Dead and
Foreign Languages, give classical and
learned air to composition, but it is doubtful
whether they give general pleasure. The
number of learnedly educated persons, is so
small, that the circle in which they can be
understood and appreciated must be very
limited; hence general diffusion OF their
influence is impossible. If men write for
the ediicaton or amusement of the public,
they should accommodate every word and
phrase to the comprehension Of those ad-
dressed. 1t is quite natural for men to ex
ercise and exhibit their attanncnts, but it is
not always expedient and pleasing Striving
to appear learned, they render themselves
obscure. They astonsh, but they do moi
please--they perplex, but they do not teach
Wrapped in their own splendor the, glide
like midnight meteors through the air, won,
dercd at, but misunderstood or incomprehen
sible. Writers would lose nothing in effec'
or celebrity by expressing themselves in the
vermacular tongue. Learned men would
understand them fully as well. and unlearn-
ed men, much better.


There is scarcely any thing more disagreed
bic to those who cannot understand it,than II
discover in the midst OF train of arguments
precepts or descriptions, sentence, phrase
or word. in foreign or dead language. Ev.
cry thing seems suddenly convulsed and
dark. A kind of deadly apoplexy seize'
the mind, and violently destroys that life
vigor and equilibrium, which buoyed it uE
through its conceptions.


1t is satisfaction to know that the Eng.
lish language is sufficiently copious to fur
nish words for the expression OF every
thought that the head can generate or i'm
bibe, or emotion the heart can feel. 1t il
in the language of Cowper,


"Expressive, energetic and refined"
Every idea may be told, every feeling trans
cribrd, and all be embellshed and beautified
The Genius of English writer's, has render
ed it perfect, and although, they are indebt
ed to foreign lands and olden times, for man,
of the materials which compose it, yet thu
workmanship and superstructure are thei
own:-they have reared splendid habita
ton, the foundation of which is indestruct'
BILE. and immovable. Then why should w
seek the empty pomp of useless learning t.
bedizen that which is independently, and IN
srinsically, fair and beneficial. II.

full articles.headline:
WILLIAM ALDRED,


DYER,
full articles.article:
Brandywine, near Wilmington,
Continues to dye Silks, SattinS, Cottons s. hsool-
ems, to any pattern they will admit of.


In consequence of the death of our late wor-
thy fellow citizen, John Fleming, goods will in
future be received at Mr. John Whites Drug
and China Store, No. 40, Market Street, Will
mngton.


After thirty two years residence, in and near
Wilmington, Wm. Aldred would feel himself un.
grateful, if he did not take this opportunity Of
returning his thanks to his friends, for their en-
ployment; and hopes their good opinion of him
will not be forfeited by any neglect in future.


February l, 1897. 20-4tp.

full articles.headline: NOTICE.
full articles.article:
All persons having demands against the estate
of George Lo,oncs, late of this Borough, decd,
are requested to present them duly attested for
settlement-and all persons indebted to said es'
tate, will make payment to the subscriber.


EZRA HOOPES, .4dm'r
Wilmington, lst mo. 29th, 1827.-20-4t.

full articles.headline: GLEANINGS.
full articles.article:
The legislature of Ohio has bill before it,
the provisions of which are intended to OPP
crate as a check on the emigration of colored
persons into that state.
Mr.. George Pain, of Upper Canada COM
mitted suicide a few days ago. by cutting his
throat Before he died he called for pen
and ink, and wrote,"I was afraid to live,
and in IA fit of insanity did this"


The Mercury stood at l9 below Zero at
Hartford, Conn. on Friday morning week.


OF the Officers and Soldiers of the Reyo-
lutlonary army, who served six months and
upwards, it is estimated that there are about
! 20, 900 now living.


quarrel took place last week between the
Captain and crew of a ship while lying at an
! chor in the East river, in which a sailor nam
ed Francis Josef was shot through the body
with pistol.


| The publication of the Alexandria Phrnix
was resumed on Tuesday. 1t has been sus-
pended since Thursday last, in consequence
of the late caiamitous fire in thas city.
| Deborah Oakley, was found dead in her
bed at Salem, IN. J.) on Tuesday last
There were marks OF violence upon her head
and face, which led to belief that she had
been murdered.


| An English country paper, describing
thunder storm, lately, says, ''several cattle
were killed; but, fortunately no lives were
lost This must be blunder to a dead GER
tainty.


An Hibernian School master, settled in a
village near London, advertises that he in
tends to keep Sunday Sch ool, twice week
| lruesdays and Thursdays1


1t is supposed in the French papers that
the English have negotiated commercial
treaty with Hayti much to the advantage of
the former.


A Scotch paper says upwards of 10000
sheep persisted iu Scotland inthe snow storms
the latter end of November last.
On Monday next grand concert is to he given
at Washington for the relief of the sufferers by
the late lire at Alexandria. The Misses Cilling.


ham and Mr. Paddon have generously volunteer
ed their aid on the occasion.


Consumptions-The New.York Times states


that the deaths in that city by Consumption,
} during the last ten years, were 6646, or nearly
one ffM of the whole number of deaths.
/ The quantity of Hops inspected in Albany, N
Y. the late three months, was So, 22S pounds.
The new building in Wall-street, New-York
occupied BY the Hope Insurance company, hav


ing front of 25 feet inches, sold at auction
, for S33, 200.





for by it said he, hear other mems impefcc
tons, and conceal my own
Justice and generosity rightly blended con
stitue a dgnfied character; but certainly so fal
!, as person is more just than generous, or more
generous than Just, that characteri is defective.
:. Women, when they marry, should legally re-
tain their maiden names as middle names, the
: husbands name being sutfxed, instead of subst
tuted. Then might we see at once OF what fam
:, lily they were.


, 1t Is said, that the Bill for the removal of the
Seat of Government from llsrrisburgh to Phila
delphia, was negatved Friday last, by a ma
I jority of nine votes


The Commissioners of Naval Hospitals, have


determined to build all asylum for invalid sailors
: and mariners, in the vicinity of Philadelphia
The present population of New-Orleans
f is believed to exceed $4,000 souls. When
} the city was transferred to this government
% years ago, it contained but 5000 inhabit-
) ants.


. Oak wood has been selling at ten dollars
/ a cord at New-York.
, The London Courier says that since the
disclaimer of Lady Foley, report has ascrib-
ed the new Novel of Almacks, to the pen OF
Lady Westmoreland.
The Memoirs of Mrs. Slddons were pub
lished December II.
UPWARDS of twenty Thousand ship letters were
received at the post-oflce in New-lork from the
9Th to the 18th ultimo inclusive. Eight thou
sand were receivcdin in one day.
A letter was lately received in Chilicothe,
from the younger Lafayette, which was only 90
days in travelling to that place from Lagrange,


via IIavre and New-York
The enthusiasm of the French nation in the
: cause of Greece continues unabated The ladies
have sold (for the benefit of that country their


cmbroierics and paintings.


From an acquaintance with the country. IN
that region, MIR. Geddes suggests that it is with,
in the compass of possibility that the "eiiand
Canal NAV turn the course of the Niagara river
: The legislature of North Carolina convened
at Raleigh on the 25th ult. and on the twenty
z sixth, Governor Burton communicated his mes
: sage. =,

J the aid of which person, although deprived OF {
t hand and part Of the arm, may be enabled Il
,vr;te q r,laiu and lcpibie hand.

full articles.headline: DIED.,
full articles.article:
Suddenly, at Philadelphia, on Tuesday evening
last, VICTOR DU PONr, Esq, native Of
France. and for many years highly respectable
and valuable citizen of Delaware.

full articles.headline: Thursday, Feb. I, 1927.
full articles.article:
Joan OF 200, ,0e0 dollars having been OBJ
,,;red in Philadelphia by the Chesapeake
..J M nelaware Canal Company, it is expect
ID that the work will progress without fur
..ar DELAY until completed. We have been
.redi.ably informed that in such high re-
.,n,. is the credit of the canal, that had so
,orre sum been wanted, 100000 could
have been readily obtained.


rhe New-York Commercial Advertiser
,,os received, by the ship Star, from ha-
.n. ,dyiccs dated 18th January; by which
:, ,rnears that Commodore Porter was at
..a, ,;me block AIDED at Key West by the
J,vapa Squadron. 1t is stated that direct
~ after I.abordc left port, in pursuit OF Por-
.er. he discovered the Mexican iieet; but
.,or found that it was not the intention OF
:,.conmandcr =. to give battle. Com Por-
,er succeeded in getting into Key west
where he was strictly blockaded. lhe 10
v.rnment of Havana we're using every ct
s,,t 10 get ready for sea the other vessels in
mort which will join Labordc as SOON as pos
eible.


F., we have received adviccs from our cor
,csnondcnt at Buenos hyres dated 31st Oc-
,ober. 1926. Our letter. bearing the Balt-
more DOS, mark, we believe was broughtby
.be brig Sylph, at Annapolis, from Rio Ja-
metro. The Captain of the Sylph states that
the English frigate Ranger arrived at Rio
IN ,he od December from Montevideo, bring
;np the Rio mail, taken from the British
nacket King Fisher from Buenos Ayres,
which latter ran on the English bank on the
10th November. Files of the "Argentne
News" directed to us, were sent by the
same vessel, but, as usual. have arf'ea oy
the 4vav. Nothing of moment had transplr-
ed by sea or land since our last dates.
Lord Ponsonby has been, quite unsuccess-
full in his attempt to settle the differences
between the Governments of Bucnos Ayrcs
and Braz-his propositions to the former
we're so unreasonable as to be rejected with
Indignation. In allusion to the English med
iation our Correspondent remarks:


"Various propositions of peace, it is said,
! have been made by Lord Ponsonby to this
Government, since his arrival, but all of so
\ unreasonable nature as to preclude all pos.
sibility of their reception. First, that the
Banda Oriental be declared independent
that independence guaranteed by G. Britain,
IN thp y,ln nf
Montevdeo and Coonia, the Republic and
and the Emperor mutually withdrawing
their forces: rejected, as may readily be
/ supposed Then, that this Government pay
IS millions Of dollars, in fifteen annual in
atalments, as a remuneration to the emperor
for the expenccs of the occupation-the
English. in this case, too, to hold Montevd-
co and Colonia, or Colonia alone. until the
payment Of the said IS million dollars be
completed, which they are to guarantee
This, which forcibly reminds one Of the an.
! ecdo,e related by the sage Doct. Franklin
/ would. truly, be paying the Brazilians 'Jo'
heating the hoker," and was likewise reject
/ ed, exciting no small degree of indignation
! in the public mind. Again, that the forces
4 Of both parties be withdrawn, and the inhab
itants of the province left freely to express
their will, as to the question of their indie
! pendence. their continuing as member o
] the Republican compact. or their incorpora
ton with the empire: freely, so far as sucl


will may freely be expressed, while the tw'


important places above mentioned, are oc


cupied by British troops, which is, still, th


appendaged condition likewise to this propo


sal.


There is something which, at the frs


blush, prescinding the British occupation


would appear fair enough in this last prop


osltion; but here, too, the Argentine Cab


met finds grand difficulty, inasmuch a


Its reception would be aifording a pre-


cedent for, and. indeed, acknowledging th


right of. province to secede, at will, from


she political association; the very principl


on which the = enarnl (sovernm ent 10 at fhi

since '32.


Counterftits.- appears from the Albany pa
pars, that nine persons were lately committed to
Jail in lIerl.imer county, N. Y. for passing coun-
terfet money. Among the spurious notes most
circulated bv this gang, are SIS and 2s on the
Geneva cank, sj's on the Chenango, SIS on the
Franklin Bank of New-york, SIS and los on
the state bank at New brunswick besides vari-
ors limitations of Phcnx, Jefferson county, and
others.


Trouble among he Bacheirs.--Cicn. M'Clure,
the hero Of Newark, has made war upon the
bachelors of New York, At the head Of an army
of Dogs and puppies! He has introduced a bin
into the Legislature of that State TO repeal the
Dog-tax, and to Levy the amount arising there
from on Bachelors between the ages of 30 and
As years. The bachelors of the city of New
York have called meeting to take measures to
prevent the passage of the bill and to express
their Indignation at the proposition.


The Liverpool Chronicle states that
Charles Lucien Bonaparte, who sailed from
New-York in the packet ship Canada. pre-
sented Captain Rogers with beautiful gold
ring, containing miniature likeness of Ma
po!eon, painted by the celebrated Isabel. 1t
is said to be superb article, and an admira-
BILE likeness of the late emperor.


Mr.. William Fletcher, Of Perqnimans, n.
G.. was lost in the schooner Perpuimans, at
sea. recently. His will has luNt been open
ed, which provides that his slaves, 10 in
number, SHALL after the ensuing year, be
emancipated; during which time they are to
be hired out, tor the purpose of raising funds
to defray the expenses of sending them ia
Havti. or Liberia, whichever they may
choose.


Sir Jtulter Scott III Pdris.--NVe have
been a good deal amused with the para
graphs which have been appearing in the
French papers. concerning our illustrious
countryman, the author of Waverly. The
good people of Paris seem to think there
must be something supernatural about him,
and attach an importance to his every word


and action, which is sufficiently ludicrous


There is no mistake more absurd, though


there are few more common, than to sup


pose that every thing that comes out of an


authors mouth must be oracular-that, be-


cause he has 1oritten books, he must also


sneak books.-As long as he retains the at


tributes of humanity, Socrates himself


must, at times, be commonplace. A Mil


ton give utterance to plain prose, and q


northern magician expressed himself moi


unlike southern Maccaroni. The simple


hearted Parisians, however, do not seem tc
have wit sufficient to make this discovery
and, accordingly, when any one was foriu'


nate enough to catch some stray sentence
!, which may have dropped from Sir Walter


Scott, at any Of their public exhibitions ol


l., Il h.., c,l lar.
: it his duty to have it set down in the letter
press, and distributed over Europe, to awe
: and delight admiring millions. We shall ia
yor onr readers with specimen of some o
this twaddle, which has been published I'm
der the name of Sir Walter Scott. We dc
not vouch for the exact words being founc
in anv one of the French Journals, but de
tails of similar interest are appearing dali,


in all OF them. yesterday great sensa


ton was excited by Sir Walter Scott's Wis
it to Galigani's reading room. lhe lllustri
B trious stranger read seven lines of the Jour


nal des Debats, and one sentence and hai


of the EtoHe. Though a little lame there Is
great deal of vivacity in the manner IL
which he walks, and the pencilling OF his
eyebrows is full of expression. We were
5 fortunate enoug to hear him remark, thai


he often loks into a newspaper with much
pleasure. .'-".rhe Great Unknown at
tracted much attention on Tuesday, by pass


ing over the Pont .Ncuf at Q O'Clock, accom-
panied by his amiabe daughter, Miss Anne
Scott-Her father directed the lady's at


tenton to the river; and in a soft but rather
melancholy tone of voice, said to her, That
is the Seine.' His daughter fixed her eyes
S upon it for moment and then both passed


on."-"Last night Sir Walter Scott was al


the Odeon. The audience thought it theii


duty to gaze intently upon him during the
whole of the evening. Sir Walter wore a


black coat, but we observed with regret that
: his ocket-handkerchicf, instead ot being o.
: white cambrick, was of yellow silk. a dis
plav of this kind, however, may not be con-
sidered breach OF etiquette in Edinburgh
= In passing the bust of Moiere in the Saioor
the Great Unknown said, in English, to
r Miss Scott, that is Moliere.' "-"This NOR
= ming Sir Waltar Scott was observed shaving
: at the bedroom window OF his hotel, in thu
q Rue 7iveH. The superiority of English ra

full articles.headline: MARRIED.
full articles.article:
On Sunday evening last. by the Rev. Lawrence
WCombs, Mr.. JAMES NOOK, to Miss MARTHA
ANN QuINBY, both of this Borough.

Trouble among Me Bacheirs.-Cen Mcclure,
the hero Of Newark, has made war upon the
bachelors of York, At the head Of an army
of Dogs and puppies! lie has introduced bill
into the Legislature of that State TO repeal the
Dog-tax, and to Levy the amount arising there
from on Bachelors between the ages of 30 and
As years. The bachelors of the city of New
York have called meeting to take measures to
prevent the passage of the bill and to express
theirindignation at the proposition.

Counterjtits.-It appears from the Albany pa
pars that nine persons were lately committed to
Jail in lIcrkimer county, N Y. for passing con-
terfeit money. Among the spurious notes most
circulated by this gang, are SIS and 2's on the
Geneva cank, s3's on the Chenango, SIS on the
Franklin Bank of New-York, SIS and los on
the state bank at New brunswick, besides vari-
ous limitations of phenix, Jefferson county, and
others.

The Liverpool Chronicle states that
Charles Lucien Bcnaparte, who sailed from
New-York in the packet ship Canada. pre-
sented Captain Rogers with beautiful gold
ring, containing miniature likeness of Ma
po!eon, painted by the celebrated Isabel. 1t
is said to be superb article, and an admira-
BILE likeness of the late emperor.

Mr.. William Fletcher, of Perqnimans, n.
G.. was lost in the schooner Psrqaimans, at
sea, recently. His will has Just been open
ed. which provides that his slaves, 10 in
number, shall, after the ensuing year, be
emancipated; during which time they are to
be hired out. for the purpose of raising funds
to defray the expenses of sending them ia
Havti. or Liberia, whichever they may
choose.

A woman of incorporate habits named
Staples, belonging to Kittery. Me. was found
dead in an engine house in Portsmouth. N.
II on the night of the 18th inst. She was
seen in that ncighborhood or hours be-
fore, and had small Jug of spirits with her
when found; she had probably perished
from cold and intoxication.


An advertisement appeared in London
paper few days ago, offering parrot for
sale. which was represented to be "perfect-
" good tempercd-could laugh sing and talk
and was well worth the attention of any
person in want of a Comhanion.


Mr.. Buchanan, OF Pennsylvania. IN his
speech in the House of Representatives, on
Friday week, said he felt proud-and well
he might-to say that "his native State had
not only paid her officers and soldiers more
literally than any other state, but had also
provided for her militia, who served during
the Revolutionary War"


II Loud CaH-A woman called at the
house of Mr.. Hays in N. Y. last evening, and
requested him to go with her, as her hus-
band had sworn to kill the first man that
came into the house, and she wanted him to
go first to protect her. We should not
think that even the high constable would be
desirous of many such calls.


The Raleigh Star says that the stage
crossed the Roanoke, near Warrenton oil
the ice, on the second instant, circumstance
which has not occurred before since '83.-
We learn that the Cape Fear was frozen
over at Ayerashrouyh also for the first time
since '82.
